add these aliases to .zshrc # Aliases
alias ll='eza -la --git'
alias cat='bat'
alias python=python3
alias pip=pip3

# Git aliases
alias gs='git status'
alias gp='git pull'
alias gc='git commit'
alias gd='git diff'
are there any other suggested edits to .zshrc?

# Navigate to a project (or create test directory)
mkdir -p ~/gemini-test && cd ~/gemini-test

# Start Gemini CLI
gemini

update the script to properly find everything

update the 1-2-3 for starting stopping postgresql
add more information on running foundationdb in the 1-2-3
update the installation script and report
install neo4j community and arangodb community edition dbs

we should create an application that can start and stop applications that are running without any complications it could be run from the terminal or with a gui, keep it simple functional utilitarian, the objective is to be able to easily start and stop tools that may be needed by which do not necessarily need to be running all of the time.
is this going to have a gui?
yes make it secure and fail safe and low overhead
can we create an icon so we can click to launch it and have it in the DOCK?

I can stop postgres but not start it
in the 1-2-3 give instructions on how to start and stop everything that could run and use resources and create a section on the start stop script
top analyze what is running what does not need to be running and what is consuming resources

what about ollama etc? write a script that I can run when I need to free memory with sudo or not
are there apple processes running that would be ok to stop?

analyze this directory create folders and cleaan up and organize

git init

git branch -M main

you need to factor that in to the app

I  DO NOT THINK THE START-ALL OR STOP ALL WORK??
LOOKS LIKE IT IS WORKING NOW
analyze this and do web search to find more information and scientific paper if possible.
continue and I added an additional markdown file that has many links which should be extracted and searched

right now create a list of each URL (ie ALL URLS in the markdown files in a new markdown file called REFERENCES which should have the URLS and a description of the material in the URL. and create a submodule .claude directory with https://github.com/coditect-ai/coditect-project-dot-claude.git

organize this directory for a project and move the markdown and research into a docs/orginal-documentation folder inside the docs folder create multiple folders for the research topics already identified

convert each of the pdfs using a combination of Google tesseract-ocr python libraries and AI LLM to create markdown documents of each paper with every attempt to extract high quaility referential quality information formatted in markdown formats.
do you need to create the folders before the extractions?

create a deep research plan with the goal of discovering based on prior research how to apply this reseaarch in CODITECT by endless learning and avoidance of catastrophic forgetting, the goal will be not to build new models but instead using memory in a variey of time frames and other techniques to be derived from Googles research and findings

call an agent (orchestrator agent for plan) with web seaarch deep search agents to find and organize the key concepts to be derived from the core research papers
CALL THE ORCHESTRATOR AGENGE WITH A PYTHON SCRIPT
I DO NOT THINK YOU GOT THE PROTOCOL FORMAT FOR AGENT CALLING CORRECT. READ THE CLAUDE.md previously referenced
do not exceed the 8k token limit

if necessary chunk the source files to break them down into 500 lines meta data headers with 5% overlap so that the data and information can be extracted and organized properly if context is exceed quality goes down better to break it down into shorter understandable chunks

should we use chroma to vb database the output and then refactor the data by semantic search with chroma to create a graph knowledge vector db that we can use to thoroughly understand the material and their relationships with the techniques we want to implement in CODITECT.
continue to advance the research plan and develop the plan and the architecture and techniquest necessary to accomplish our research plan
i added additional research in the original documentation folder in a new subfolder (how should we handle new research mid project cycle?
we need to continue to convert the PDFs to markdown in preparation for chunking and subsequent CHROMA databasing for the research pdfs ingestions

analyze every file and and if text and the text is formated as markdown, rename the file type .md for markdown and do not change content, any other text files that are not markdown, reformat and organize the content without dropping or removing concepts data or information and re-write the documents as markdown .md files

echo "# claude-code-functionality-tools-research" >> README.md
git init
git add README.md
git commit -m "first commit"
git branch -M main
git remote add origin https://github.com/coditect-ai/claude-code-functionality-tools-research.git
git push -u origin main

so for this research project we have assembled a baseline of source material with the goal of advancing our understanding of the way in which Anthropic is advancing CLAUDE CODE  and expanding the tool, concepts etc. OUR LONG TERM OBJECTIVE IS to not only understand, but ultimately advance CODITECT, with the advances but also make it generally avaialable accross and useful with all LLMs with that in mind how should we advance our research and development for CODITECT? ADD this also as another submodule which is some work that I was doing previously in this area of standardization and functionality across many 3rd party llm providers in addition to Anthropic. https://github.com/coditect-ai/az1.ai-coditect-agent-new-standard-development.git
git add commit push https://github.com/coditect-ai/claude-code-functionality-tools-research.git and update the README.md and create a CLAUDE.md at the project ROOT
this is not an MIT license, everything is closed source AZ1.AI INC. Copyright 2025 Hal Casteel CEO/CTO EMAIL 1@az1.ai
analyze the reports the markdown tables are messed up in github the way that they are displaying go through the entire project and finish formating and organizing, presentation is important

next step research and examples create a detailed task level breakdown of the research project plan and create it with distinct sprints that can can be processed agentically autonmously and with python scripts to automate the data management and processing. prepaare the scripts the plan with check boxes that will be checked off as the project runs to the end autonmously, everything orchestrated by agent and processed by other agents specifically by use case and work flow by the appropriate agent, do the analysis (call the Orchestrator agent) for planning and develop the entire project plan and the scripts to kick it off and run it agentically.

Why the Future of AI Won’t Be Built on Transformers.txt has been added to the Transcripts subdirectory, it needs conversion to markdown using our latest tools for converstion and addition to the original-source for the research project
update the README.md and CLAUDE.md at the project ROOT with the current STATE

given all we are adding how are we going to make sure that we do not hid context llm limits and the economics, we should should the internal search process, research, plan, script the agent, skill, command, hook choices to reduce the context explosion rather ie pick and choose rather than overload the system with too much context for a given task, as part of a greater project, smaller tasks, better choices, fewer tokens. Suggestions?

  proper command selection:

⏺ Excellent question! CODITECT has a multi-layered guidance system to ensure proper command and agent
  selection. Here's how to use it:

  🎯 The 4-Layer Guidance System

  Layer 1: Quick Reference 📚

  File: .coditect/docs/SLASH-COMMANDS-REFERENCE.md (just created!)

  Use when: You want a quick lookup of all 72 commands

  # Quick scan for the right category
  Planning & Strategy → /deliberation, /strategy, /create_plan
  Implementation → /implement, /action, /prototype
  Code Review → /analyze, /ai_review, /full_review
  Testing & Quality → /test_generate, /tdd_cycle

  ---
  Layer 2: Decision Tree 🌳

  Command: /COMMAND-GUIDE

  Use when: You're unsure which command fits your task

  # Ask the guide
  /COMMAND-GUIDE

  # Shows you decision tree:
  What do you want to do?
  ├─ Plan/Design? → /strategy, /deliberation
  ├─ Research/Verify? → /research, /research_codebase
  ├─ Implement? → /implement, /prototype
  └─ Review/Analyze? → /analyze, /local_review

  Plus workflow patterns:
  - Full Feature Development (8 steps)
  - Quick Feature (3 steps)
  - Bug Fix (3 steps)
  - Performance Work (3 steps)

  ---
  Layer 3: Agent Selection 🤖

  Command: /suggest-agent [what you want to do]

  Use when: You need the right agent invocation syntax

  Example:
  # Input
  /suggest-agent "optimize database queries"

  # Output
  "Use the foundationdb-expert subagent to analyze and optimize 
  database performance including query patterns and schema efficiency"

  ---
  Layer 4: Intelligent Dispatcher 🧠

  Command: /agent-dispatcher [detailed request]

  Use when: Complex tasks requiring multiple agents or orchestration

  Example:
  /agent-dispatcher "implement user authentication with tests and documentation"

  # Provides:
  - Primary recommendation
  - Alternative options
  - Multi-agent coordination if needed
  - Reasoning for selection

  ---
  🔄 Recommended Workflow

  For Simple Tasks:

  1. Check SLASH-COMMANDS-REFERENCE.md → Find command
  2. Use command directly: /implement, /analyze, etc.

  For Complex Tasks:

  1. /COMMAND-GUIDE → Understand workflow pattern
  2. /suggest-agent → Get agent invocation syntax
  3. Execute suggested invocation

  For Multi-Step Features:

  1. /agent-dispatcher → Get full workflow recommendation
  2. Follow orchestrated sequence
  3. Use /COMMAND-GUIDE for individual steps

  ---
  💡 Practical Decision Matrix

  | If you want to...    | Use                         | Why                         |
  |----------------------|-----------------------------|-----------------------------|
  | Quick lookup         | SLASH-COMMANDS-REFERENCE.md | See all 72 commands at once |
  | Understand workflow  | /COMMAND-GUIDE              | Learn step-by-step patterns |
  | Get agent syntax     | /suggest-agent              | Generate correct invocation |
  | Complex coordination | /agent-dispatcher           | Multi-agent orchestration   |

  ---
  🚀 Quick Start Examples

  Example 1: "I need to implement a feature"

  # Option A: Direct (if you know the pattern)
  /implement user-profile-editing

  # Option B: Get guidance first
  /suggest-agent "implement user profile editing feature"
  # Then use the suggested invocation

  # Option C: Full workflow guidance
  /COMMAND-GUIDE
  # Follow "Pattern 1: Full Feature Development"

UPDATE with this content: Steven Rosenbush
Companies Begin to See a Return on AI Agents
The widespread belief that business is still waiting on agents to prove their worth might not last much longer
Steven Rosenbush
By 
Steven Rosenbush
Follow
Nov. 12, 2025 7:00 am ET





Gift unlocked article

Listen

(5 min)


Attendees gather outside Moscone Center at the 2025 Dreamforce conference.
Enterprise AI agents were the headliners at a Salesforce conference in San Francisco last month. Michael Short/Bloomberg News

Quick Summary





BNY says it has about 100 “digital employees” with distinct logins.
View more

Few companies today have widely deployed AI agents and gotten value back, one of many reasons that concerns are growing over the astronomical spending on artificial intelligence. But don’t overlook those early adopters who say the payoff is looking good.

The pack could appear prudent in the not-so-distant future for waiting to see how agents mature, or the first movers might gain a long-term, sustainable advantage. I have tried to be open to either outcome, or some combination of the two. It could be that the vanguard crew, the fast followers and the laggards all have good reasons for taking different approaches, and that as long as they execute well on their own time frames, things will work out.

But now, as more AI agents come out of the pilot stage, there is evidence to support the early adopters. I had the opportunity to speak with two of them last month at the Gartner IT Symposium/Xpo in Orlando, Fla., where I participated in a panel pointedly called “Agentic AI: Is it Real?”

“It’s very, very hard to build an agentic framework,” said Leigh-Ann Russell, chief information officer and global head of engineering at financial services provider BNY, during our conversation on stage. “But we have 117 solutions [including agentic] touching everything that happens at the bank and we’re seeing really, really tangible outcomes that impact our bottom line in terms of growing capacity.”

Newsletter Sign-up

WSJ | CIO Journal

The Morning Download delivers daily insights and news on business technology from the CIO Journal team.


Preview

Subscribe
In perhaps the most dramatic example, Russell said the company has about 100 “digital employees” that possess their own distinct login credentials, communicate via email or Microsoft Teams, and report to a human manager, a system designed to provide a framework for managing, auditing and scaling the agent “workforce.”

One “digital engineer” at BNY scans the code base for vulnerabilities, and can write and implement fixes for low-complexity problems.

The agents are built on top of leading models from OpenAI, Google and Anthropic, using additional capabilities within BNY’s internal AI platform Eliza to improve security, robustness and accuracy.

Walmart uses AI agents to help source products, informed by trend signals such as what teenagers are buying at the moment, according to Vinod Bidarkoppa, executive vice president and chief technology officer at Walmart International, and another panelist.

In the fashion industry, it takes around six months to design and produce a collection of clothing, from ideation and concept building to the day items end up in stores and online. Walmart’s Trend-to-Product agent shortens the traditional production timeline for Walmart fashion by as much as 18 weeks. Trend-to-Product has helped create specifications and patterns for products such as Walmart’s No Boundaries Off-Shoulder Mini Dress.

AI is a “force multiplier” that will lift productivity across all lines of business, particularly in engineering, where significant increases are already visible, but not a means to replace human decision-making, Bidarkoppa said. “This is real value, if all of these agents are working together,” he said.

Advertisement


Some of that work is also behind the scenes, which might help explain the general sense that we are still waiting on agents to deliver more value. “Walmart is a good example of a customer now working with us on the commerce side, but also using a lot of our technology internally around things like how to merchandise, how to handle risk and so on, on their site,” OpenAI Chief Financial Officer Sarah Friar said Nov. 5 at the WSJ Tech Live conference.

Early studies reporting low adoption rates and nonexistent returns might have created more drag on agents’ reputation. These studies weren’t necessarily wrong, but I suspect they were snapshots in time that might have lured some into concluding the entire effort was destined to misfire.

BNY’s Russell referred to a Massachusetts Institute of Technology study that generated headlines last August because it reportedly found most generative-AI pilot projects had failed to generate meaningful returns. “For us, that’s a hard false,” Russell said. MIT didn’t respond to a request for comment.

There are other signs of agentic life. Software-as-a-service giant Salesforce told me it has seen “5x growth” since the launch of its Agentforce platform last year.

This is just another moment in time, of course, far from the end of the story. Adoption remains in the early stages. Plenty of trial, error and spending lie ahead. But when it comes to the usefulness of AI agents, an important demonstration of efficacy has been established by some first movers in the market.

cr have we documented this somewhere?   - These 3,771 messages are stored in MEMORY-CONTEXT/dedup_state/unique_messages.jsonl
  - Each message is stored only once globally, even if it appears in multiple session exports
  - The deduplication system tracks which messages belong to which sessions via watermarks and hashes

  So whenever you export and deduplicate a conversation, the system:
  1. Checks each message against the 3,771 existing unique messages
  2. Only adds truly new messages to the global store
  3. Updates session watermarks to track message positions

  This ensures zero data loss and perfect session reconstruction while minimizing redundant storage. /generate-project-plan What Will Break

  Immediate Breaks (Must Fix)

  | Item            | Impact                                            | Fix Effort        |
  |-----------------|---------------------------------------------------|-------------------|
  | .gitmodules     | All submodule URLs invalid                        | 30 min (scripted) |
  | install.sh URLs | raw.githubusercontent.com/halcasteel/coditect/... | 15 min            |
  | update.sh URLs  | Same                                              | 5 min             |
  | CI/CD workflows | Any repo name references                          | 30 min            |

  Temporary Issues (GitHub Handles)

  | Item            | Impact                     | Duration                     |
  |-----------------|----------------------------|------------------------------|
  | Old GitHub URLs | Auto-redirect to new names | ~1 year                      |
  | Existing clones | Remote URLs outdated       | Users run git remote set-url |
  | Bookmarks       | Old URLs redirect          | Permanent redirects          |

  Won't Break

  | Item                  | Why Safe                       |
  |-----------------------|--------------------------------|
  | Internal code imports | Use relative paths             |
  | Local file references | Paths don't include repo names |
  | Package dependencies  | Not published to npm/PyPI      |
  | Database connections  | No repo name dependencies      |

  ---
  Realistic Effort Estimate

  | Task                          | Time   | Can Script?                |
  |-------------------------------|--------|----------------------------|
  | Rename repos on GitHub        | 1 hour | Partially (gh repo rename) |
  | Update .gitmodules            | 30 min | Yes                        |
  | Update install.sh/update.sh   | 20 min | Manual                     |
  | Update READMEs (find/replace) | 1 hour | Yes (sed)                  |
  | Update CLAUDE.md files        | 30 min | Yes                        |
  | Update CI workflows           | 30 min | Manual review              |
  | Move to subfolders            | 1 hour | Scripted                   |
  | Test everything               | 1 hour | Manual                     |

  Total: ~6-8 hours of focused work

  ---
  Risk Mitigation

  1. GitHub redirects protect external links
  2. Do it in one session - don't leave half-renamed
  3. Script the bulk changes - reduce human error
  4. Test install.sh immediately after updating URLs

  ---
  Bottom Line

  Low risk, medium effort. The main pain is the volume of changes, not the complexity. Most "breaks" are
  just URL updates that we control.

  Want me to start executing? I can begin with:
  1. Generate the complete rename script
  2. Start with consolidations (merges)
  3. Or do a dry-run first to show exactly what changes

write this into the original research as another text file: Large language models alone will never produce a fully autonomous system.

Anyone who has tried to make a robot operate reliably already understands that.

The missing pieces aren’t mysterious. 

They’ve been mapped out for years in cognitive robotics, even if some of the required components are still beyond current capabilities.

From my experience in humanoid robotics, the following architecture captures what a genuinely autonomous agent actually needs:

- The high-frequency perception and action loop at the bottom handles raw sensory input, motor commands, and tight real-time constraints. This layer reacts quickly and keeps the system stable.

- The situation assessment layer sits in the middle. It maintains a world model, updates internal state, detects inconsistencies by comparing the world model prediction with the reality, and triggers exploration when reality contradicts expectations. This is the bridge between reflexive behavior and deliberate cognition (dealing with that layer was my PhD work).

- The top deliberative layer manages intent, supervises behavior, and performs high-level planning. This is where goals are formed, simulations run, and abstract intentions turn into concrete actions that cascade downwards.

Each layer operates at its own timescale, and autonomy emerges from the interaction between them. No single model can replace the entire stack. Real autonomy requires coordinated perception, memory, reasoning, and action.

The diagram above is a simplified view, but in my opinion it is the most practical and technically grounded blueprint for building a truly autonomous agent.

Deep learning usually dominates the lower layers today, especially in perception and control. But that picture is beginning to shift with recent advances in AI.

Even in a future where a single large model plays a bigger role than we expect (for example it make sense to use a LM, but not alone, in the supervision layer), its functions will differ drastically depending on the layer, and each role will still need to be managed within a broader neuro-symbolic framework.

True autonomy isn’t a monolith, it’s a system. and credit Yoan Sallami, PhD
